media.caption: Hiroshima or Nagasaki after bombing

text.headline: Idaho, World War II... Timeline
text.text: On December 7th, 1941, Japan's surprise military attack on the Pearl Harbor military base in Hawaii not only was the catalyst for the United States entering World War II, but also had a drastic effect on the lives of Japanese immigrants and Japanese-Americans living in the United States. This exhibit looks at the experiences of the Japanese communities in and around Idaho during World War II.

media.caption: Letter from President Dale to University of California, Berkley's President Sproul

text.headline: Letter from President Dale to University of California, Berkley's President Sproul
text.text: President Dale informs President Sproul that the University of Idaho would be willing to accept a limited number of Japanese-American student transfers from University of California, Berkley.

media.caption: Letter from University of California, Berkley's President Sproul to President Dale

text.headline: Letter from University of California, Berkley's President Sproul to President Dale
text.text: President Sproul inquires if the University of Idaho would accept Japanese-American students that were being forced to relocate away from the University of California, Berkley.

media.caption: Letter from James B. Hughes to President Dale

text.headline: Letter from James B. Hughes to President Dale
text.text: Pastor Hughes from First Baptist Church in Coeur d'Alene, Idaho encourages President Dale to allow Japanese students to relocate to the University of Idaho.

media.caption: Letter from University of California, Berkley's President Sproul to US Vice-President Henry A. Wallace

text.headline: Letter from University of California, Berkley's President Sproul to US Vice-President Henry A. Wallace
text.text: President Sproul notifies Vice-President Wallace of a proposal for how to address Japanese American citizens who were being removed from univesities along the West Coast.

media.caption: Evacuees Not At All Bitter

text.headline: Evacuees Not At All Bitter
text.text: Sub-headed 'American Japanese to Be Evacuated From Coast; Declares Loyalty.' This article relates the feelings of Tom Hirashima a Japanese American being relocated from Santa Barbara.

media.caption: The Japanese Evacuation: Looking Backward and Forward

text.headline: The Japanese Evacuation: Looking Backward and Forward
text.text: Article in a religious magazine about the relocation of Japanese citizens and how readers can help.

media.caption: Our Closed Door

text.headline: Our Closed Door
text.text: Article written by K.C. on the University of Idaho's policy to not allow Japanese American students to transfer from out-of-state instutitions due to forced relocation.

media.caption: Letter from Asher B. Wilson to President Dale

text.headline: Letter from Asher B. Wilson to President Dale
text.text: Wilson urges President Dale to only allow Japanese students who are Idaho citizens into the university, at least until the Board of Regents meets to make an order.

media.caption: Letter from L.P. Sieg to President Dale

text.headline: Letter from L.P. Sieg to President Dale
text.text: President Sieg assures President Dale that the six Japanese students sent to Moscow were sent before they had received word that the University of Idaho would not accept them.

media.caption: Letter from President Dale to Asher B. Wilson

text.headline: Letter from President Dale to Asher B. Wilson
text.text: President Dale responds to Asher B. Wilson detailing the events that led to six Japanese students coming to Moscow.

media.caption: Letter from Robert W. O'Brien to Professor Paul K. Hatt

text.headline: Letter from Robert W. O'Brien to Professor Paul K. Hatt
text.text: Robert W. O'Brien from University of Washington discusses moving the six Japanese students sent to Moscow to Pullman.

media.caption: Nisei Sent Here to be Taken Out

text.headline: Nisei Sent Here to be Taken Out
text.text: Article on R.W. O'Brien's trip to Moscow to discuss with President Dale the removal of six Japanese American students who had been sent to Moscow.

media.caption: Six Nisei Students Come Here to Continue Studies

text.headline: Six Nisei Students Come Here to Continue Studies
text.text: Article details the arrival of six Japanese American students from the University of Washington in Moscow.

media.caption: Letter from President Dale to Governor Clark

text.headline: Letter from President Dale to Governor Clark
text.text: Letter to Governor Clark addressing mis-represented facts in a Spokesman-Review article where the governor was interviewed.

media.caption: Letter from Governor Clark to President Dale

text.headline: Letter from Governor Clark to President Dale
text.text: Letter to President Dale detailing the Governor's desire that those with Japanese ancestry should not be allowed to relocate and settle in the State of Idaho, but be "brought here under proper guard." He also states that Japanese Americans should put aside their education for the duration of the war and put themselves to work on something that would help win the war.

media.caption: Public Proclamation No. 3

text.headline: Public Proclamation No. 3
text.text: Proclamation by General J.L. DeWitt establishing regulations over all with Japanese ancestry within the Military Areas established by Public Proclamations Nos. 1 and 2. This proclamation established curfews and limited their movements. It also probihibited the possession of firearms, bombs, radio transmitting sets, cameras, and other items. This proclamation did not solely apply to those of Japanese ancestry, but also alien Germans and Italians.

media.caption: Six American Citizens

text.headline: Six American Citizens
text.text: Article written by K.C. on the removal of six Japanese students from Moscow.

media.caption: An Open Letter to Governor Clark

text.headline: An Open Letter to Governor Clark
text.text: Open letter to Governor Clark printed in Washington State Evergreen. The letter criticizes Governor Clark's attitude and actions towards those of Japanese ancestry being relocated to Idaho, particularly the treatment of those who had been relocated to Moscow.

media.caption: Letter from Representative Don C.D. Moore to President Dale

text.headline: Letter from Representative Don C.D. Moore to President Dale
text.text: Letter questioning the decision to not allow non-resident Japanese American students to enroll in the University of Idaho.

media.caption: Letter from Representative Don C.D. Moore to President Dale

text.headline: Letter from Representative Don C.D. Moore to President Dale
text.text: Letter addressing the university's policy to not allow "out-of-state" Japanese American students to the University of Idaho. He states that the university of Idaho may have the authority to ban all "out-of-state" students from attending the university, to limit it to just Japanese "out-of-state" students is discriminatory and against not only the state constitution, but the 14th Amendment of the US Consititution.

media.caption: Letter from Japanese American Citizens League to the University of Idaho

text.headline: Letter from Japanese American Citizens League to the University of Idaho
text.text: The Japanese American Citizens League requests a message from the University of Idaho President to include in an upcoming publication of The Pacific Citizen.

media.caption: Letter from President Dale to E.J. Baldwin

text.headline: Letter from President Dale to E.J. Baldwin
text.text: Letter regarding the possible acceptance of a Japanese American student to the University of Idaho-Southern branch.

media.caption: Letter from Allan C. Lemon to Student Relocation Counsellor Haru Tanabe

text.headline: Letter from Allan C. Lemon to Student Relocation Counsellor Haru Tanabe
text.text: Letter informing Haru Tanabe that President Dale and the Board of Regents were receiving further consideration.

media.caption: Letter from Student Relocation Counsellor Haru Tanabe to Allan C. Lemon

text.headline: Letter from Student Relocation Counsellor Haru Tanabe to Allan C. Lemon
text.text: Letter from Haru Tanabe inquiring whether the University of Idaho would accept a Japanese American student who was interested in taking forestry classes.

media.caption: Letter from Frank N. Freeman to J.F. Messenger

text.headline: Letter from Frank N. Freeman to J.F. Messenger
text.text: Letter from the University of California, Berkeley Dean of the School of Educating informing the J.F. Messenger at the University of Idaho that they have a plan to allow Japanese students to work in education and practice teaching at the Relocation Centers.

media.caption: Letter from President Dale to Student Relocation Counsellor Haru Tanabe

text.headline: Letter from President Dale to Student Relocation Counsellor Haru Tanabe
text.text: Response to letter Haru Tanabe regarding the admittance of relocated Japanese American students.

media.caption: Letter from State Superintendent of Public Instruction C.E. Roberts to President Dale

text.headline: Letter from State Superintendent of Public Instruction C.E. Roberts to President Dale
text.text: Letter stating that the Board of Regents of the University of Idaho has voted to not allow non-resident Japanese Americans to enroll in on-campus or correspondence courses.

media.caption: Letter from President Dale to Commander Rex Gross

text.headline: Letter from President Dale to Commander Rex Gross
text.text: Response to letter from Commander Gross of the American Legion in Potlatch, Idaho about the treatment of Japanese American students at the University of Idaho.

media.caption: Letter from Commander Rex Gross to President Dale

text.headline: Letter from Commander Rex Gross to President Dale
text.text: Letter from Commander Gross of the American Legion in Potlatch , Idaho expressing concern over the attitudes expressed by some people in Moscow towards Japanese students at the University of Idaho.

media.caption: Letter from Acting Dean Baldwin to the Edward V. Berman at the War Relocation Authority

text.headline: Letter from Acting Dean Baldwin to the Edward V. Berman at the War Relocation Authority
text.text: Letter to the War Relocation Authority informing them that the University of Idaho-Southern Branch was unable to accept Japanese-American students at the time. Baldwin also notes that with the addition of the Navy's V-12 officer training school at the branch there has been some prejudice against enrolled Japanese American students.

media.caption: University Makes No Change in Jap Policy

text.headline: University Makes No Change in Jap Policy
text.text: Article on the how six Japanese-American students were brought to Moscow and the University's stance.

media.caption: Group Hears Martin Tell Slap-A-Jap Club's Idea

text.headline: Group Hears Martin Tell Slap-A-Jap Club's Idea
text.text: Article on the formation and plans of the "Slap-a-Jap" Club as a war fundraiser for students.

media.caption: Letter To The Editor

text.headline: Letter To The Editor
text.text: Letter to the Editor by Mrs. M.H.G. criticizing the name of the "Slap-a-Jap" Club.

media.caption: It Takes All Kinds

text.headline: It Takes All Kinds
text.text: Response to the Letter to the Editor by Mrs. M.H.G. defending the name of the "Slap-a-Jap" Club.
